Probably the best non-Japanese shmup ever created, Jets n Guns easily earns it's reputation as being one of the most addictive and diverse shooters in the genre.

The game is a classic shooter that plays horizontally similar to classic horishmups such as Metal Black, Einhander, or the legendary Gradius and R-type series but is very different with it's colorful, creative, and humorous comicbook style. Oh, and just about the raddest and baddest soundtrack you'll ever hear for a videogame.

Jets N Guns Gold has by far more content and challenge to offer than just about any shooter before it, with a campaign that took me at least a year to complete on Normal.  This is a game you'll want to play multiple times, and upgrades/weapons carry over, so beating it on Easy is only the beginning.

The challenge is there in full force but without being too impossible for newcomers thanks to a hugely robust weapon catalogue and upgrade system, all it takes is a little tinkering and you'll be on your way to becoming a Jets N Guns master!

reviewText:
This game is gawddamned awesome!

Inspired by legendary SHMUPs (read: Tyrian), Jets'n'Guns is an explosive action horizontally scrolling destroy'em'up with a splendid soundtrack by Machinae Supremacy.

It's based around Tyrian-like structure of progression, where you complete levels and upgrade your ship between them, with an option to pick up extra upgrades (and secret stuff!) during the levels. There's also an occasional boss you'll have to fight, as well as several unique levels where you zip around in your spacesuit instead of being in your ship. Also like in Tyrian and Raptor, you have a rather ample supply of armor (and repair options), so it's quite a bit more comfortable to play than the Japanese-type 1-hit-and-you-dead shoot'em-ups.

The story is wacky and rather nonsensical, as are the weapon, level and enemy designs (there's a gun that literally shoots Superman clones, you pick up secret duckies along the way, and there's the borg-like alien race which is literally beer) and the game doesn't really take itself very seriously, but it creates a strangely interesting atmosphere which I really liked.

It's hard as nails, too! Don't expect any hand-holding, and expect to die and restart levels- or even the entire game, because you CAN screw up your ship build and it WILL turn out to be impossible to complete later levels if you don't know what you're doing. I recommend playing on a lower difficulty level to begin with and get familiar with the game mechanics (which boil down to kill as many things as you can because you really need all the money you can get").

I'm really glad this game found its way on Steam- it has my full recommendation!"

reviewText: I'd forgotten how good this game is; I played it for hours back when it was first released. If you like side-scrolling shoot em ups, or just crazy shooting mayhem in general, you really can't go wrong with it. Fair warning, it's damn hard! Play on easy if you can't take the challenge, but normal is just enormous fun. When you die, you're back in the action within a couple of seconds, and you'll thank the devs for that because you'll die a lot. The gameplay is complete madness, everything is trying to kill you, and when you shoot down anything or blow up any ground installation, the guys manning it stream out or fall to their deaths, and you can smear them across your windscreen or riddle them with plasma as you wish. Sounds gory, and it is, but it's pretty mild cartoon violence unless red pixels horrify you. Before long (ie. 5 seconds onto the start of the level) there are bullets, bodies and pixel blood spots flying everywhere, explosions and crashing planes triggering more explosions, all set to a rockin' heavy metal / chip soundtrack that still sounds great. If that doesn't appeal to you, you should probably seek therapy! Gameplay wise, each level begins with a shop where you can buy, sell or upgrade your weapons and a selection of fun components that do everything from highlight wanted bounty hunters to earning you millions by streaming your exploits to a TV show (!). More mundane components do things like improve your hull or heat dissipation. The varied selection of weapons, bombs and ships is essential to understand if you want to progress in the game, particularly on the harder difficulties, because specific ship / weapon setups are much better than others at handling certain levels, the fun lies in trying different combos. Can't get past that bit on level 2? Go back to the shop and try another combination. I suppose the only downside is due to the age of the game it doesn't support multiple resolutions, although you can play it windowed at native res or full screen at whatever resolution you're using. Frankly it looks fine, the art holds up well, and once the chaos begins you'll hardly notice.\n\nSo yeah, it's just about the most fun you can have while scrolling to the right. Highly recommended if you're remotely into this genre.

reviewText:
I remember playing this game years ago as a child, so finding it on steam was a pleasant surprise.  Great graphic style and music still hold up to this day, although some things are a tad dated (I'm looking at you, resolution).

The game has a fairly steep learning curve, with 3 starting difficulties (I went with hard and the first few levels were brutal until I got the hang of the game).  Shooting down ships earns the player precious credits, so depending on how OCD the player is, this may lead to an easy or difficult late game, although I think the game generally tends towards being slightly easier (especially leading up to the brutal last boss fight); if you're really stuck the game also lets you cheat fairly easily for the price of being branded a cheat and presumably disabling steam achievements.

For most of my hard mode playthrough, difficulty rose at an appropriate level to keep me challenged without being unfairly difficult, although some weapons are noticably better/worse than their counterparts.   You could take this as a positive or negative thing depending on your outlook; most weapons have a clear use for at least one difficulty setting/level and beyond that player can intentionally downgrade to flashier (and weaker) gun as a handicap or the cool factor.

It can be difficult to see enemy projectiles at times, but this is only really an issue when the player has lots of flashy weapons shooting at the same time, which I only really found a problem on the second playthrough, at which point you're pretty much invincible anyway.

For me, the game only stopped being enjoyable when it became too easy and I had time to be bored; this really only happened in my second playthrough where I cleared the hard waves instantly and then had nothing to do or dodge until the next wave spawned.  For this reason I'd suggest trying the game on at least normal or hard difficulty for maximum enjoyment and replay value.

Overall I'd recommend this game if you're seeking a fun shooter that doesn't take itself too seriously and (mostly) challenges you in a fair way.

JETS’N’GUNS! It delivers what it promises, but the ship doesn’t look like a jet, BUT THAT’S ALRIGHT CAUSE YOU GET TO SHOOT THE HELL OUT OF EVERYTHING! I’m sad that I found this game so late. I should be shot into the sun for that.

This has become one of my all time favorite games. Its a horizontal shooter with the ability to “pimp your ship”. Choose a body, load it up with guns and fly out. ALSO, the game allows you to sell your stuff for the same price you bought it for, so go nuts and play around with the loadout to your hearts content. That alone made it a standout game and something to recommend to anyone new to shoot-em-ups.

If you’re a beginner, or just aren’t good at these types of games, start on “Too fat to die” so you can build currency. Every time you beat the game the game goes up a difficulty level and a good deal of them you can only access on beating the game through additional playthroughs and certain guns you can only get by playing on higher difficulties. ALSO your currency carries over in each playthrough.

A word to the wise. Their are several segments where you’ll be asked to leave your ride for another one. While some can be annoying, others can be enjoyable and help break up the monotony. Also, aftr going through one that drove you nuts makes getting back to shooting everything in your own ship of choice that much sweeter.

The only complaint I have with the game is that once these segments are over, you need to retweak your ship and the fact that you cannot save loadouts. Its annoying, but not enough for me to turn people away from it.

Its an old game, but its an old game that hold up VERY WELL. If you call yourself a fan of the shoot-em-up genre you are doing yourself a disservices by passing this up.

Just love this game. For me it's the best Shoot 'em up released in the last decade. Ship and weapons are highly customizable and come in big numbers. Also, there are a lot of added game mechanics like hacking things with a device or opening cargo crates in a small mini game. The humour is pretty much tongue-in-cheek, but somehow manages it to not get too silly.

And not to forget: the great soundtrack by Machinae Supremacy. Anyone loving chiptunes and/or metal should give this game a try for this soundtrack alone.

One thing I have to remark though is the high difficulty. This game is certainly not for the easily frustrated. But it never gets unfair and I always managed to beat the levels if I just played them enough. That's not common these days, but it was perfectly normal back in the days.

Bottom line: hard but rewarding horizontal shoot 'em up with great soundtrack.

reviewText:
Kinda-hardcore old-school side-scroller with terrific music. And sense of humor. And lots of blood, and dozens of levels, and metric ****ton of weapons, and space hot-dog as a possible ship (horrible, actually), and secret level where you can kill spammers. Basically, the best and last of its kind, I haven't seen a better one since JnG original release 9 years ago. A word of advice, don't flatter yourself and start the game on easy or normal, you'll have a chance to replay the higher difficulties (and then the hardest difficulties) as NewGame+ and the game can be brutal in the start. Don't be afraid to experiment with ships and loadouts (and don't forget you can and should upgrade the ship's systems), you can always sell everything at the same price you bought it - a simple mechanic that surprisingly few games uses right - and at least several levels need specific loadouts for you to be effective.

The negative side is that the game was released 9 years ago. The gameplay has aged very well, the graphics - not so. I strongly suggest to play it in window mode so you won't have to look at blurred 800x600 graphics in full screen. The game graphics itself are beautiful, but the scaling to higher resolutions could be better.

Last thing: ok, I pirated this. About 8 years ago, I think, cause I've never seen the official game as a physical copy and I didn't have a credit/debit card for a long time. And it was one of the few games I actually felt terrible about, because I wanted to do everything I can to raise the chance of JnG2 happening. So now I'm finally buying this, and buying some copies for my friends (many of which have already played and loved it back then), and writing this review, and will actually spam some people about buying it. Just make a sequel and you'll have my money.

reviewText:
When I saw this on steam, I instantly bought it. I have completed the game at least 20 times (over 120 hour playtime) and still enjoying.
This game is a side scrolling shoot them up game with lots of weapons, upgrades, enemies lots of hidden secrets en much more. What makes this shump so good? I will sum it up for you.

Graphics/sounds/music:
I love them all. Explosions are satisfying. Music are made from a real band!

Enemies:
A great variety of enemies. From tiny troops that you can kill by “touching” them with your ship to a horrific boss. During the game you will face pirates, aliens, mutants and even zombies! Ohh, zombies I really love them. There is a map with tons of them. They throw brains to you lol. Anyways in that map, you are willing to buy a tool “TV show cast” (can’t remember its name exactly). That tool will stream your killing action to the world as entertainment. For you as player, you will earn a  very nice amount of money for every multi kill. It goes from multikill (5 kills at once) to massacre (a lot of kills at once) to annihilation (name says all).

Weapons:
The amount of different weapons is massive. At some point, you can buy weapons that the bosses has used against you.  How amazing is that? Those weapons can be upgraded. Some weapons can be upgraded 3 times, other more than 6 times.  What I love in this game is, you will never lose your money. Every weapons/upgrades you bought, you can sell it back for the price you have bought.  It means, you can try any combo infinitely. Believe me, you will need it on normal difficulty already.
Weapons has four categories: Front, rear, bombs and missile

Ships:
These are really important. Different ships has different pros and cons. Some ships allows you to buy special tools, like ship repair, better shields, a time vortex to slow down the game on demand in hectic situation etc. Other ships allows you to carry more weapons from different weapon category (front, rear, and missile). Every ship has different amount of health/shield/heat sink.

Secrets:
There are many different secrets in this game to be discovered. There are secret maps, no spoiler on this. There are secret weapons. I love the tomato shooter and the baseball stick. Both awesome and useless at the same time. However, there are strong secret weapons ingame. Secret weapons cannot be bought. You can only get them by finding them on specific missions. If you want x times of a secret weapon, you need to complete game x times. Secret ship models, gotta love it. if you ever wanted to fly in a ship like one of the bosses you have faced. I wish you good hunting to this secret.

Other nice things:
In game, you can collect cargo that is locked. When you have finished the mission. You are willing to unlock these cargos. In order to unlock, you need to buy a Hacking tool. It is like a simplified mastermind game. Another nice thing is bounty hunter. You might catch a criminal. When you finished the game, you can do 2 things with him. Delivering him to the cops and claim the money prize or let the criminal bribe you. When you allow him to bribe you, you can get nothing or up to twice the money the cops are offering. Choose wisely…
Almost finished.

Replay value:
You might be wondering why I completed the game more than 20 times and still playing.
There are three things that increase the replay value.
1) Every time you have completed a game, you will continue at mission 1 with a higher difficulty. You have read it right, you will CONTINUE. It means that you keep everything that you have unlocked/bought. That is nice, you can test if your strongest weapon can handle the normal difficulty.
2) Even more powerful  weapons will only be unlocked when you play the game for the second time. These weapons are strong, but it comes with a price. You need to complete the game several times to get enough money to buy x times of it + fully upgrade them. This will keep you busy for a while.
3) Did you found all secret maps, ships and weapons? You want x times of that secret weapon? Then you need to complete the game x times.

Overall, this shump is highly customizable. Very nice replay value with many secrets that keeps you busy.  Something I really like.
Gl hf
Note: When you play this for the first time, I highly recommend easy difficulty.

The ultimate fiery and bloody experience, for less than a Taco Bell meal. What are you waiting for?

Butt jokes aside, this is a sidescrolling shmup with between-level upgrade shop, unlimited lives and respec, enough firepower for at least a half dozen other games, and an absurd action movie sendup plot. In a genre that makes people scared of the ground, JnG frequently encourages you to grind your spaceship along it so you can run over dudes. Sometimes it outright kicks you out of your spaceship to buzz around with a jetpack and two guns bigger than you are.

This thing got rejected from both Steam and GoG before for some reason.

It's also in my top three eye-searingly colorful games next to Cargo and Warframe.

EDIT: OH YEAH, START ON EASY. Each time you finish, it automatically loops to the beginning and advances difficulty. Normal is essentially Dark Souls NG+, and you are NOT going to have a good time if you start on that.

Ah, one of my favorite side-scrolling shooters ever. Why?

reviewText:
I usually don't write reviews, but I rarely encounter games as good as Jets'n'Guns Gold. Inspired by Tyrian 2000, Project-X, Walker, R-Type, and Darius, this old school side-scrolling shooter offers wicked difficulty as well as wicked charm.

Instead of collecting weapons akin to R-Type, this game takes a page from Tyrian where you have the option of buying weapons after you complete each level. And trust me you are going to need to upgrade as soon as possible because each level gets progressively more and more difficult. Gamers looking for a breeze need not apply because it is not easy.

The graphics to J'n'G are reminiscent of an old 2D side-scrolling shooter. Nothing to hold in high acclaim, but still very nice to look at. Has kind of computer 90s feel. J'nG Gold also offers a comic book intro and outro to each level(or at least during the first few levels, I haven't gotten too far into it), which is also very nice.

Oh and the music? Fantastic!  Machinae Supremacy and its sister production company, Hubnester Industries does a fantastic job at providing a heavy metal and chiptune atmosphere. Trust me, the music definitely adds a lot to already great game.

If you like great side-scrolling shooters, please buy this game. It's $3 right now, but even if it is $6.99 J'nG is still worth the price.

reviewText:
Tries to have its cake and eat it, too.

The spectacle scrolling shooter is a wonderful thing. Beautiful visual effects... missiles on top of lasers on top of bombs on top of fireballs on top of smoke on top of debris. The skill based scrolling shooter is also a wonderful thing. Learning patterns and avoiding death by knowledge and reflex is satisfying once executed to perfection. This game combines the two into an off-putting mush. It's incredibly difficult to determine what will and won't instantly kill you behind all those pretty visuals. The result is that often times you die and are not sure why. Combine this with infrequent checkpoints and it's the recipe for frustration.

Pushing the difficulty down from Normal to Easy is a necessity. It substantially reduces the number of things that will instagib you, but not so much that you won't still end up playing the same five minute segments a half dozen times before completing them. Jets'n'Guns fails the Super R-Type test... meaning you'd be better of playing Super R-Type. Here's a free to play browser version: http://www.snesfun.com/game.php?id=1224

The upgrade system is compelling. The humor is compelling. The B-movie sci-fi Di ck Tracy story presentation between levels is compelling. The gameplay is fatally flawed. If instant or sub-second death is a feature, then the threats must be clear, and the checkpoints must be frequent. How odd that Jets'n'Guns makes me want to play more Super Meat Boy....

reviewText:
Jets'n'Guns is a mixture of bullet hell, reverse bullet hell (where you build your own insane firepower), ship customization, and your usual side-scroller.  Loud, crazy, brash, with plenty of enemies, guns, and weiredness, it's an extremely satisfying shooter.

You play as . . . well the plot gets kind of bizarre, but sort of a soldier turned mercinary, who goes out to save the universe by blowing up spaceships, trucks, troops, building, jets, monsters, and everything else.  As you play you earn money, unlock equipment, find hidden weapons, and far, far more.  Eventually you're customizing your own spacecraft with all sorts of crazy weaponry as you find new ways to defeat your enemies.

Customization and gameplay is a big part of this.  Pick the right loadout in order to survive, pick your battles, and react fast to survive.  The wrong loadout or bad tactics can kill you - and you may need to replay a level and/or recustomize your ship to get things right.  Fortunately, anything you buy can be traded in for full price, encouraging all sorts of combos.

Pretty much a must-pick up for a side scroller/bullet hell player.  But a few caveats:
1) The bullet hell aspect is also based around enduring attacks and being willing to take hits.
2) At times the game screen can get crowded if you build your own bullet-spewing monstrosity, so don't just think a big loadout saves the day - you might not even be able to see your ship in all the chaos.
3) The plot is utterly bizarre and it's hard to tell how much is parody, throwaway jokes, actual humor, or just plain craziness.  There's also some elements that may be parodies of sexist tropes, but the plots are so crazy it's hard to know.

reviewText:
I love a good shoot em up, but this is not that.  The weapons are horribly underpowered, the enemies lack any of the rhythm that often defines the genre, and most of the time your screen winds up obscured by smoke or unnecessary debris from whatever you blew up, making it impossible, combined with the enemy firing rate and general blurriness of the graphics, to discern what is and is not a bullet.

Yeah, it's challenging, but unlike other games, you never learn from your death, and it always feels like you're unaware of why exactly you died.  Some scenery can be fired through, some inexplicably cant (but enemies can).  Some of it will damage you, some of it may not.  Bullets are so small and obscure looking that picking them out of the other effects is often impossible to do.  On top of that, controller and graphics options are a joke, and the responsiveness of the controls is pretty horrible.

The only bright spot is the music, which is fantastic.  Other than that, this game was a waste of money, even at the discounted price of $3.50.

reviewText:
To say this game is unpolished would be a bit of an understatement.

You have 3 choices for controls in this game: keyboard, mouse, and controller. In all 3 control methods (yes, even the mouse) you either don't move at all or you move at one unchangeable speed. Moving the mouse slowly simply results in you not moving at all, making it unresponsive and unintuitive. And no, you can't configure the deadzone. If using a controller, you also can't map the triggers to anything, so you'll need another program such as joy2key or qjoypad unless you want to be holding down a button for the whole game. Basically, the controls could not possibly be made any worse than they are right now.

In addition to the crappy controls, there's no visual indication whatsoever when you take damage. The bullets were also kind of hard to see when something exploding sends harmless particles and rubble flying around obscuring the things that actually do damage.

The interface is also pretty annoying. Instead of having a healthbar somewhere easy to see, it uses a circular guage for your health and stuffs it in the bottom left of the screen, which is particularly annoying if you're playing fullscreen. You can't change its position or size either.

reviewText:
WOW am I glad I came across Jets'n'Guns. I got it on a whim after seeing it under the recently released Steam games and knowing my interest in weird SHMUPs. I had never heard of it beforehand so this is a strictly no-nostalgia-goggles review.

To put it simply, Jets'n'Guns is the MOST western, gross looking, and FUN SHMUP I have ever played on PC. I say western because it is the polar opposite of a eastern bullet hell anime Touhoufest. The game is very enjoyable for casual SHMUP players like me who really sucks at SHMUPS, though I had to kick it down to Easy mode the first time through. The game's design is gross... but that's not bad... it makes you feel like you're playing what it is: a Windows 98 game that doesn't give a crap about what it looks like. YES, you WILL see Comic Sans. YES, you WILL not care because you're having so much fun. ALSO: The music is pretty great... prog metal with a chiptune backdrop.

Gameplay all about throwing as much firepower as possible at the enemy ships. You do this by collecting cash from every kill and using it on upgrades between each level. By the end of the game you will have SOOO MANY UPGRADES you won't know what to do with them. Make sure to experiment as much as possible with different combinations: I was not aware it didn't charge you more for selling back weapons for a while.

TL;DR: Get this if you want a gross looking but satisfying SHMUP with a huge upgrade system.

reviewText: Everything about this game screams greatness. This game has some of the finest side-scrolling, platforming, shmup action that I have played and I go back to the Jungle Hunt years. There is no lack of challenge and once you think it starting to get easier, you get hit with the wake up call that forces you to completely change your strategy. I found myself playing this one again after I beat it on normal, just so I could blow everything up with overly powerful weapons to find out that there is even more content than I thought. I'm currently on my 3rd go though playing it on hard for a new challenge. This game has way more replayability than I expected. The one thing that bugged me about this game is that a few levels had some really cheesy enemies as well as few lame weapons but these a minimal in contrast to the rest of the game. What made this even more character along with the explosions and violence was the humor and found myself chuckling in the middle of battle a few times. There is no shortage of levels, enemies, weapons, secrets and customizable ships. The controls seemed a little sensative at first but easy to overcome in a very short amount of time. Sounds were good with the 80's hair band music that seemed to fit the style of gameplay. The graphics get insane at times and I was amazed at how quickly the screen could fill up with weapon shots, enemies, explosions, etc... that you can easily get lost in the madness. I would highly recommend this to anyone and a definate picker-upper. I give this a 9 out of 10. -1 for the few levels that you are going to say ooooh gawd

reviewText: I've been playing this game for years and it's still one of the best shoot em ups I've ever played. What truly sets this apart from others like it are the weapons. You have dozens of weapons to customize your ship with and dozens upon dozens of combinations to experiment with. And each weapon feels different, whether it's in the weapons speed, style of destruction, or type of combat. The art is great, the gameplay animation is excellent, the game is long with many levels to give you hours of entertainment. Of particular note are the writing, story, and music. The story and writing are silly, parodying most sci-fi, space operas, but it's still well written and entertaining to follow. And the music is one of the big standouts of the game. Created by Swedish metal band Machinae Supremacy, it's probably one of the best soundtracks for an indie action game I've ever heard, crafting a professional, well produced metal and electronic soundtrack. If you're a shoot em up fan and you haven't given Jets N Guns a try, you're missing out on a truly classic indie gem.

There are no lives, so every level can be retried until the player beats it. There are checkpoint inside levels, but forfeiting the current try sends the player back to the start of the current level.

A big pro considering the previous release is that the devs added joystick support to menus! So the cursor can be comfortably controlled with the players weapon of choice. :)

Every play-through adds a small amount of content, so replayability is great. And this game has that oldskool hook" that there are a lot of secrets and hidden content to be found (think of the 3rd / 4th gen. video games) so it makes the player want to play it again and again with the thought "maybe this time I'll find that thing" in mind.

Shoot 'em Up fans will not be disappointed. 11 / 10"

reviewText: I've been playing this game for years and it's still one of the best shoot em ups I've ever played. What truly sets this apart from others like it are the weapons. You have dozens of weapons to customize your ship with and dozens upon dozens of combinations to experiment with. And each weapon feels different, whether it's in the weapons speed, style of destruction, or type of combat. Most of the fun you have will be from trying out the different weapons and finding the most effective ones to use. But beyond the weapons, everything else is top notch for an indie shooter, which is what has made the game such a classic over it's many years of being around. The art is great, the gameplay animation is excellent, the game is long with many levels to give you hours of entertainment. Of particular note are the writing, story, and music. The story and writing are silly, parodying most sci-fi, space operas, but it's still well written and entertaining to follow. And the music is one of the big standouts of the game. Created by Swedish metal band Machinae Supremacy, it's probably one of the best soundtracks for an indie action game I've ever heard, crafting a professional, well produced metal and electronic soundtrack. If you're a shoot em up fan and you haven't given Jets N Guns a try, you're missing out on a truly classic indie gem.

reviewText:
Jets'n'Guns is a heavy piece of ground shaking rock blasting action with graphics and special effects that will blow you eyes out! Well, that's the tagline. In truth it's a 2d side scrollin shmup with average graphics and awesome soundtrack.

Playing this for the first time on normal difficulty reminded me of Dark Souls - you died, you died, you died, you... I know. Holy crap the game is punishing. The graphics, nice as it is, helps your enemies by hiding their bullets more often than not. Still, it's fun. You pilot one of several airplanes slash starships, fit it with guns, rockets, bombs and other weapons of mass destruction. Then you go and kill everything that moves in more than 40 levels of mayhem.

Murdering everything took me about 15hrs, at the end the explosions from my guns covered the whole screen and there was no way in hell to discern what's going on. It was cool. There is NG+ where you can start all over with upgraded stuff. For the first half of the game everything dies by just looking at you. This time you died mutha♥♥♥♥az!

I liked:
* soundtrack
* lots of weapons
* shooting stuff
* the fact that you could skip story panels (haven't read one, i was so eager for shooty shooty bang bang)

I disliked:
* first part is hard as nails, while the end is almost easy mode
* sometimes, and nerer the end quite often, you have no idea what's going on due to all the flashy bang bangs

Get this:
* if you like shmups

Don't get this:
* if you need your shmups to have cutting edge graphics
* if you cannot handle the difficulty (well, I guess you could always play on easy)

reviewText:
Presentation
This brilliant little 2D space shooter immediately hooks you with its fantastic heavy metal soundtrack by Machinae Supremacy.

Have a listen!

You can find the entirey soundtrack in .ogg format in the game's install folder (usually 'C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\SteamApps\common\JnG Gold\MUSIC' - may be different if you've chosen a different file path for Steam during Steam's installation or if you've chosen a different install path for this game).

Speaking of metal, the amount of carnage and destruction you are able to unleash in this game is unlike anything I've ever seen. This title is worthy of its pounding, energetic soundtrack.

Visuals may be low-res and 2D, but effects still look great and the amount of things going on at the same time on the screen is very impressive. Needless to say, this game runs on almost any machine made within the last fifteen years.

Gameplay
Jets'n'Guns is a very challenging game (even on easy), but thanks to the upgrade system being remarkably flexible and allowing for many different play styles, you can overcome its sometimes punishingly hard levels - you can just sell any item, weapon or upgrade without being financially punished and experiment with a new configuration. Incredibly tight controls, no matter if you're using keyboard, mouse, gamepad or joystick, also alleviate some of the difficulty. Level and enemy design are more creative and varied than anything you've ever seen (except for somewhat disappointing boss fights) and everything is neatly tied together by a completely insane story (but in a good way - the ending alone is ingenious).

Conclusion
Jets'n'Guns is cheap, 100% bad ♥♥♥, yet intelligent, has plenty of replay value and will forever be one of my favorite games.
